title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over a year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). "1203 stock" refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment of the Act. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock in a qualified small business C corporation. The stock must be acquired in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services, and publicly traded on a domestic stock exchange at the time of sale. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock in a qualified small business C corporation. A qualified small business is defined as a domestic C corporation with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. Market capitalization for determining gain exclusion under the Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 is calculated by multiplying the closing price of a share of stock by the number of outstanding shares at the end of the reporting period before the acquisition date. The reporting period, as defined for determining gain exclusion under the Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004, refers to the period for which the most recent annual or quarterly report is required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires periodic information under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Aggregation rules apply, and additional rules similar to those of section 1202 are enforced. The Securities and Exchange Commission enforces rules similar to section 1202, with amendments to sections 642(c)(4) and 643(a)(3) of the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including 643(a)(3), 691(c)(4), 871(a)(2), and 1044(d), by inserting references to sections 1202 and 1203. Additionally, a new subsection is added to section 1202 for "Section 1203 stock." Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including 643(a)(3), 691(c)(4), 871(a)(2), and 1044(d), by inserting references to sections 1202 and 1203. A new subsection is added to section 1202 for "Section 1203 stock." Sales and exchanges under section 1203 are not considered under this section. The amendments made by this section apply to securities acquired after the date of the enactment of this Act.
